Since we now have a version of the identity theorem in mathlib, I'm trying to write a version which matches wikipedia's statement more closely - in particular using accumulation points. My understanding was that docs#cluster_pt is how mathlib talks about accumulation points, but stating the theorem like this

lemma identity_theorem {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ} {D S : set ‚ÑÇ}
  (hfD : analytic_on ‚ÑÇ f D) (hD : is_open D)
  (hD' : is_connected D) -- probably preconnected is enough
  (hSD : S ‚äÜ D) (hfS : S.eq_on f 0) {z : ‚ÑÇ}
  (hz : cluster_pt z (ùìü S)) : -- z is an accumulation point of S
  D.eq_on f 0 :=

can't work (it's not hard to show this is false). So what am I misunderstanding here? Presumably it's about accumulation points vs cluster_pt, but I can't quite figure it out
I commeted about this here: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/16489#discussion_r971039654
Ah I see, so docs#cluster_pt on principal filters doesn't correspond to accumulation points of sets, thanks!
Don't you simply want the analogue of cluster_pt but with punctured neighborhoods?
I mean ùìù[‚â†] x instead of ùìù x
Ah, so hz should instead be (hz : (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot)? That seems reasonable to me
Indeed it is suspicious that cluster_pt doesn't give back the right notion for set. Maybe mathlib's definition is not the right one. We should check that.
I checked the definition of cluster point of a filter is the same in Bourbaki and in mathlib.

Patrick Massot said:

I checked the definition of cluster point of a filter is the same in Bourbaki and in mathlib.

Hmm, does this then mean that cluster points of filters don't align as closely as I guessed to cluster points of sets?
No, it's just that cluster points and accumulation points are in general different concepts.
(At least, with the terminology I am used to)

Jireh Loreaux said:

No, it's just that cluster points and accumulation points are in general different concepts.

In this case I'm confused at the docstring for cluster_pt, which says that these are also called accumulation points

aha, well, Wikipedia says my version of the terminology is nonstandard. It says that cluster point, accumulation point and limit point are all synonymous (with punctured nhds definition), and that adherent point is what mathlib currently calls cluster point. (I've never heard anyone use the term "adherent point" before though.)
Personally, I've frequently heard "cluster point" or "limit point" for the nhds version, and "accumulation point" for the punctured nhds version, but maybe I have just been exposed to weird sources.
It's pretty clear there are different notions and people disagree on terminology. It simply means we need to write really clear docstrings.

Jireh Loreaux said:

(I've never heard anyone use the term "adherent point" before though.)

This may come from French. In French the closure of a set is called the "adh√©rence" of the set.

It's getting late here so I wrote a blunt proof.

import topology.subset_properties

open_locale filter topological_space

open filter set

example {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±] {S : set Œ±} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  simp_rw inf_principal_ne_bot_iff,
  by_contra' H,
  apply hS',
  simp_rw [‚Üê ne_empty_iff_nonempty, not_ne_iff] at H,
  choose! U hU hU' using H,
  have : ‚àÄ x ‚àà S, insert x (U x) ‚àà ùìù x,
  { intros z hz,
    exact insert_mem_nhds_iff.mpr (hU z hz) },
  rcases hS.elim_nhds_subcover (Œª a, insert a (U a)) this with ‚ü®T, hT, hT' : S ‚äÜ ‚ãÉ x ‚àà T, insert x (U x)‚ü©,
  have : S = T,
  { apply subset.antisymm _ hT,
    intros z hz,
    specialize hT' hz,
    simp only [mem_Union, mem_insert_iff, exists_prop] at hT',
    rcases hT' with ‚ü®y, H, rfl | hzy‚ü©,
    exact H,
    exfalso,
    have : z ‚àà U y ‚à© S, from ‚ü®hzy, hz‚ü©,
    rwa hU' y (hT y H) at this },
  rw this,
  exact T.finite_to_set
end
It's really not polished at all, but it types-check.
Thank you!

    hS.elim_nhds_subcover (Œª a, insert a (U a)) (Œª z hz, insert_mem_nhds_iff.mpr (hU z hz)),

example {S : set ‚ÑÇ} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  let f := hS'.nat_embedding S,
  obtain ‚ü®‚Ñì, h‚Ñì, œÜ, hœÜ1, hœÜ2‚ü© := hS.is_seq_compact (Œª n, (f n).prop),
  refine ‚ü®‚Ñì, h‚Ñì, inf_principal_ne_bot_iff.mpr (Œª U hU, _)‚ü©,
  have h3 := hœÜ2 (insert_mem_nhds_iff.mpr hU), simp at h3,
  have h4 : ‚àÉ N, ‚àÄ n, N ‚â§ n ‚Üí (f n).val ‚â† ‚Ñì,
    { by_contra',
      obtain ‚ü®n‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÅ, h'‚ÇÅ‚ü© := this 0,
      obtain ‚ü®n‚ÇÇ, h‚ÇÇ, h'‚ÇÇ‚ü© := this (n‚ÇÅ + 1),
      linarith [f.inj' (subtype.coe_injective (h'‚ÇÅ.trans h'‚ÇÇ.symm))] },
  obtain ‚ü®N, hN‚ü© := h4,
  obtain ‚ü®N', hN'‚ü© := h3,
  specialize hN' (N ‚äî N') le_sup_right,
  specialize hN (œÜ (N ‚äî N')) _,
  refine le_sup_left.trans (hœÜ1.id_le _),
  refine ‚ü®f (œÜ (N ‚äî N')), _‚ü©,
  simp [hN, hN'],
  exact hN'.resolve_left hN
end

Generalization to any topological space:

import order.filter.basic
import topology.subset_properties
import topology.basic

open_locale filter topological_space

example {X} [topological_space X] {S : set X} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  contrapose! hS',
  simp_rw [filter.not_ne_bot, filter.inf_principal_eq_bot, mem_nhds_within] at hS',
  have := hS.elim_nhds_subcover' (Œª z hz, S·∂ú ‚à™ {z}) (Œª z hz, _),
  { obtain ‚ü®t, ht‚ü© := this,
    refine set.not_infinite.2 ((t.finite_to_set.image $ Œª x : S, x.1).subset $ Œª x hx, _),
    specialize ht hx, simp_rw set.mem_Union at ht,
    obtain ‚ü®y, hy, hx'|hx'‚ü© := ht,
    exacts [(hx' hx).elim, ‚ü®y, hy, hx'.symm‚ü©] },
  { obtain ‚ü®u, hu, hzu, hs‚ü© := hS' z hz,
    simp only [mem_nhds_iff, set.union_comm],
    exact ‚ü®u, set.diff_subset_iff.1 hs, hu, hzu‚ü© },
end
The idea is that if S has no accumulation point then every point is isolated so it's a discrete subspace of X, which is compact iff it's finite.

Of course we weren‚Äôt talking about filters but the generalization is pretty straightforward. The proof I‚Äôve been taught is the one Junyan describes, and I think that this is the right one but we don‚Äôt have the API ready for this. Basically I think any mathlib proof should go through docs#finite_of_compact_of_discrete.

We might also be able to cook up a direct proof not going through covers, but I think we want to have all the API to make that proof trivial anyway, so I don‚Äôt think it is a problem to transitively use covers

That said, Adam's suggestion does look nice, at least in the non-relative case:

import topology.subset_properties
import order.filter.ultrafilter

open_locale filter topological_space

open filter set

lemma foo (Œ± : Type*) [topological_space Œ±] [compact_space Œ±] [infinite Œ±] :
  ‚àÉ z : Œ±, (ùìù[‚â†] z).ne_bot :=
begin
  let f := hyperfilter Œ±,
  have : ((f : filter Œ±) ‚äì ùìü {f.Lim}·∂ú).ne_bot,
  { rw ‚Üê not_mem_iff_inf_principal_compl,
    exact (finite_singleton _).nmem_hyperfilter },
  exact ‚ü®f.Lim, @@ne_bot_of_le this (inf_le_inf_right (ùìü {f.Lim}·∂ú) f.le_nhds_Lim)‚ü©
end

Going from the absolute case to the relative case is then a bit annoying, but here it is:

example {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±] {S : set Œ±} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  haveI : compact_space S := is_compact_iff_compact_space.mp hS,
  haveI : infinite S := hS'.to_subtype,
  rcases foo S with ‚ü®‚ü®z, hzS‚ü©, hz‚ü©,
  refine ‚ü®z, hzS, @@ne_bot_of_le (@@filter.map_ne_bot (coe : S ‚Üí Œ±) hz) _‚ü©,
  rw [nhds_within, nhds_within, map_inf subtype.coe_injective, inf_assoc, inf_principal,
      map_principal, ‚Üê subtype.image_preimage_coe, preimage_compl],
  refine inf_le_inf (continuous_subtype_coe).continuous_at
    (principal_mono.mpr $ monotone_image $ compl_subset_compl.mpr _),
  rintros x (rfl : coe x = z),
  ext,
  refl
end

import topology.subset_properties
import order.filter.ultrafilter

open_locale filter topological_space

open filter set

lemma map_coe_le_principal {Œ± : Type*} {S : set Œ±} {f : filter S} : map coe f ‚â§ ùìü S :=
le_principal_iff.mpr $ @@mem_of_superset (@univ_mem _ f) (Œª x _, x.2)

example {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±] {S : set Œ±} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  simp_rw [nhds_within, inf_assoc, inf_principal],
  haveI : infinite S := hS'.to_subtype,
  let f : ultrafilter Œ± := ultrafilter.map coe (hyperfilter S),
  rcases hS.ultrafilter_le_nhds f map_coe_le_principal with ‚ü®z, hzS, hz‚ü©,
  have : ((f : filter Œ±) ‚äì ùìü ({z}·∂ú ‚à© S)).ne_bot,
  { rw [‚Üê compl_compl S, ‚Üê compl_union, ‚Üê not_mem_iff_inf_principal_compl],
    change coe ‚Åª¬π' _ ‚àâ hyperfilter S,
    rw [preimage_union, subtype.preimage_coe_compl, union_empty],
    exact ((finite_singleton _).preimage $ subtype.coe_injective.inj_on _).nmem_hyperfilter },
  refine ‚ü®z, hzS, @@ne_bot_of_le this (inf_le_inf_right _ hz)‚ü©
end

Here is my proposal filling API holes for the finite_of_compact_of_discrete route:

import topology.subset_properties

open_locale filter topological_space

open filter set

lemma filter.principal_eq_map_coe_top {Œ± : Type*} (s : set Œ±) : ùìü s = map (coe : s ‚Üí Œ±) ‚ä§ :=
by simp

open filter

lemma filter.inf_principal_eq_bot_iff_comap {Œ± : Type*} {f : filter Œ±} {s : set Œ±} :
  f ‚äì ùìü s = ‚ä• ‚Üî comap (coe : s ‚Üí Œ±) f = ‚ä• :=
by rw [filter.principal_eq_map_coe_top s, ‚Üê filter.push_pull',inf_top_eq, map_eq_bot_iff]

variables {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±]

lemma discrete_topology_iff_nhds : discrete_topology Œ± ‚Üî ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ùìù x = pure x :=
begin
  split ; introI h,
  { intro x,
    rw nhds_discrete },
  { constructor,
    apply eq_of_nhds_eq_nhds,
    simp [h, nhds_discrete] },
end

lemma discrete_topology_iff_nhds_neq : discrete_topology Œ± ‚Üî ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ùìù[‚â†] x = ‚ä• :=
begin
  rw discrete_topology_iff_nhds,
  apply forall_congr (Œª x, _),
  rw [nhds_within, inf_principal_eq_bot, compl_compl],
  split ; intro h,
  { rw h,
    exact singleton_mem_pure },
  { exact le_antisymm (le_pure_iff.mpr h) (pure_le_nhds x) }
end

lemma subtype.discrete_topology_iff {S : set Œ±} : discrete_topology S ‚Üî ‚àÄ x ‚àà S, ùìù[‚â†] x ‚äì ùìü S = ‚ä• :=
begin
  rw [discrete_topology_iff_nhds_neq, set_coe.forall'],
  apply forall_congr (Œª x, _),
  rw [filter.inf_principal_eq_bot_iff_comap, nhds_within, nhds_within, comap_inf, comap_principal,
      preimage_compl, ‚Üê image_singleton, function.injective.preimage_image subtype.coe_injective,
      nhds_induced]
end

lemma is_compact.finite {S : set Œ±} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : discrete_topology S) : S.finite :=
finite_coe_iff.mp (@finite_of_compact_of_discrete _ _ (is_compact_iff_compact_space.mp hS) hS')


example {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±] {S : set Œ±} (hS : is_compact S) (hS' : S.infinite) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà S, (ùìù[‚â†] z ‚äì ùìü S).ne_bot :=
begin
  by_contra' H,
  simp_rw not_ne_bot at H,
  exact hS' (hS.finite $ subtype.discrete_topology_iff.mpr H),
end

import topology.subset_properties

open_locale filter topological_space

open set

namespace filter
lemma principal_eq_map_coe_top {Œ± : Type*} (s : set Œ±) : ùìü s = map (coe : s ‚Üí Œ±) ‚ä§ :=
by simp

lemma inf_principal_eq_bot_iff_comap {Œ± : Type*} {f : filter Œ±} {s : set Œ±} :
  f ‚äì ùìü s = ‚ä• ‚Üî comap (coe : s ‚Üí Œ±) f = ‚ä• :=
by rw [filter.principal_eq_map_coe_top s, ‚Üê filter.push_pull',inf_top_eq, map_eq_bot_iff]

lemma ne_bot_of_comap {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} {F : filter Œ≤} (h : (comap f F).ne_bot) : F.ne_bot :=
begin
  rw ne_bot_iff at *,
  contrapose! h,
  rw h,
  exact comap_bot
end
end filter

open filter

variables {Œ± : Type*} [topological_space Œ±]

lemma discrete_topology_iff_nhds : discrete_topology Œ± ‚Üî ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ùìù x = pure x :=
begin
  split ; introI h,
  { intro x,
    rw nhds_discrete },
  { constructor,
    apply eq_of_nhds_eq_nhds,
    simp [h, nhds_discrete] },
end

lemma discrete_topology_iff_nhds_neq : discrete_topology Œ± ‚Üî ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ùìù[‚â†] x = ‚ä• :=
begin
  rw discrete_topology_iff_nhds,
  apply forall_congr (Œª x, _),
  rw [nhds_within, inf_principal_eq_bot, compl_compl],
  split ; intro h,
  { rw h,
    exact singleton_mem_pure },
  { exact le_antisymm (le_pure_iff.mpr h) (pure_le_nhds x) }
end

lemma subtype.nhds_within_eq_bot_iff {s t : set Œ±} {x : s} :
  ùìù[(coe : s ‚Üí Œ±) ‚Åª¬π' t] x = ‚ä• ‚Üî ùìù[t] (x : Œ±) ‚äì ùìü s = ‚ä• :=
by rw [inf_principal_eq_bot_iff_comap, nhds_within, nhds_within, comap_inf, comap_principal,
       nhds_induced]

lemma subtype.nhds_ne_eq_bot_iff {S : set Œ±} {x : S} : ùìù[{x}·∂ú] x = ‚ä• ‚Üî ùìù[{x}·∂ú] (x : Œ±) ‚äì ùìü S = ‚ä• :=
by rw [‚Üê subtype.nhds_within_eq_bot_iff, preimage_compl, ‚Üê image_singleton,
       subtype.coe_injective.preimage_image ]

lemma subtype.nhds_ne_ne_bot_iff {S : set Œ±} {x : S} :

I'm not sure I agree with this, especially if one of our goals is to cover the whole undergrad curriculum and be accessible to "normal mathematicians" who know about accumulation points and not about filters. They would likely prefer either x ‚àà closure (S \ {x}) or perhaps ‚àÉ·∂† z in ùìù[‚â†] x, z ‚àà S (which I always read in my head as "there is a sequence tending to x, except without the pathological stuff about sequences not appearing because something something filter). That being the same as a statement in terms of principal filters, which indeed make some proofs easier further down the line, is an "implementation detail", and IMHO should be hidden from the API.

After all we do have a definition of continuous_at in mathlib even though we could inline it everywhere as tendsto f (ùìù x) (ùìù (f x)) :grinning:

The cluster_pt definition was already introduced for the sake of having more readable statements. This has a cost since every definition must come with lemmas, otherwise the first step in any proof is always to unfold the definition. But if there are sufficiently many statements that would benefit from the definition then it can be worth the trouble. So you can try. Note also that tendsto f A B is already a somewhat useless wrapper around the core definitions which are docs#filter.map and docs#filter.partial_order, and map f A ‚â§ B is actually shorter to type and more evocative. And you can read ‚àÉ·∂† z in ùìù[‚â†] x, z ‚àà S as "there exist a point near x but different from x that belongs to S", without thinking in terms of sequences.

Agreed on everything, except that very few people in math departments would find map f A ‚â§ B on filters to be more evocative than tendsto or continuous_at :-) and tendsto is not so useless if it is close to everyday mathematicians' use while at the same time enabling dot-notation use in proofs.

I was partly joking about ‚àÉ·∂† (only partly because depending on the kind of math one is doing, "you can find a point arbitrarily close to x" and "you can find a sequence that converges to x" can feel indistinguishable), but I maintain that informal mathematicians would prefer it to cluster points of filters...

Sure, I wasn't suggesting we get rid of tendsto, this was an argument in favor of keeping "useless" definitions. It would still be nice to have more mathematicians thinking in terms of filters, but this is unlikely to happen.
